definitions.definition: to risk money on a race or an event by trying to predict the result
definitions.sensetop: bet on/against somebody/something doing somethingbet on/against somethingbet something on somethingbet somethingbet somebody something (that)bet somebody (that)bet something (that)

examples.text: You have to be over 16 to bet.
I wouldn't bet on them winning the next election.
Not many people are betting against France retaining their title.
He likes betting on horses and watching table tennis.
He bet $2 000 on the final score of the game.
You shouldn't praise a gambler for betting his life savings if he wins.
She bet me £20 (that) I wouldn't do it.
I bet her (that) the Democrats would not win.
He bet ten dollars (that) he could write a complete story in just six words.

definitions.definition: used to say that you are almost certain that something is true or that something will happen

examples.text: You can bet (that) the moment I sit down, the baby will wake up.
I'm **willing to bet** (that) the analysts will be wrong.
I’ll bet you (that) he knows all about it.

definitions.definition: to risk everything you have on an investment, a bet, etc.

examples.text: The company bet the farm on the new marketing model, only to find that it wasn’t successful.

definitions.definition: used to show that you can understand what somebody is feeling, describing, etc.

examples.text: ‘I nearly died when he told me.’ ‘I bet!’

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody that you do not believe what they have just said

examples.text: ‘I'm going to tell her what I think of her.’ ‘Yeah, I bet!’

definitions.definition: used to say that you do not think that something is very likely

examples.text: ‘She'll soon get used to the idea.’ ‘I wouldn't bet on it.’

definitions.definition: used instead of ‘yes’ to emphasize that somebody has guessed something correctly or made a good suggestion
used to say that you are certain that something will happen

examples.text: You can bet your bottom dollar that he'll be late.

wordOrigin: late 16th cent.: perhaps a shortening of the obsolete noun abet ‘abetment’.
